abate.definition: to become less intense or widespread
abate.etymology: Middle English: from Old French abatre ‘beat down’, from a- (from Latin ad ‘to, at’) + batre ‘to beat’.

avarice.definition: extreme greed for wealth or material gain
avarice.example: His avarice led to his downfall.
avarice.etymology: Middle English: from Old French, from Latin avaritia, from avarus ‘greedy’, from avēre ‘desire’.

banal.definition: lacking in originality; obvious and boring
banal.example: His banal comments added nothing to the conversation.
banal.etymology: Late 18th century: from French, literally ‘having no veil (to conceal the face)’, from ban ‘proclamation, ban’.

candor.definition: the quality of being open and honest in expression
candor.example: She spoke with great candor about her struggles.
candor.etymology: Middle English: from Old French, from Latin candor, from candere ‘to shine’.

deleterious.example: The deleterious effects of smoking are well known.
deleterious.etymology: Early 17th century: from Greek dēlētērios ‘noxious’, from dēlētēr ‘destroyer’.

abstemious.definition: not self-indulgent, especially when eating and drinking
abstemious.example: He had an abstemious lifestyle, never consuming more than a single glass of wine with dinner.
abstemious.etymology: From Latin abstemius, from ab- (without) + *temous, from temetum (intoxicating drink).

cognizant.definition: having knowledge or awareness of something
cognizant.example: As a teacher, she was always cognizant of her students' needs and tried her best to meet them.
cognizant.etymology: From Latin cognoscere (to get to know, recognize), from co- (together) + gnoscere (to know).

enervate.definition: to weaken or deprive of strength; to make lethargic
enervate.example: The heat of the day enervated him, causing him to feel drained and sluggish.
enervate.etymology: From Latin enervare, from e- (out of) + nervus (nerve).

garrulous.definition: excessively or pointlessly talkative; using too many words
garrulous.example: The garrulous woman at the party monopolized the conversation, making it difficult for others to get a word in edgewise.
garrulous.etymology: From Latin garrulus (talkative), from garrire (to chatter, prattle).

mendacious.example: The politician's mendacious statements caused many to question his integrity.
mendacious.etymology: From Latin mendax (lying), from mendum (fault, error) + -ax (inclined to).

exacerbate.definition: to make a problem or bad situation worse
exacerbate.example: Her angry response only exacerbated the situation.
exacerbate.etymology: from Latin exacerbatus, past participle of exacerbare, from ex- 'thoroughly' + acerbus 'harsh, bitter'

querulous.definition: complaining in a petulant or whining manner
querulous.example: The patient was in a querulous mood and complained about everything.
querulous.etymology: from Latin querulus 'full of complaints', from queri 'complain'

ludicrous.definition: so foolish, unreasonable, or out of place as to be amusing
ludicrous.example: The idea of a pig flying was ludicrous to the farmer.
ludicrous.etymology: from Latin ludicrus, from ludicrum 'a play, game, joke'

plethora.definition: a large or excessive amount of something
plethora.example: There was a plethora of food at the banquet.
plethora.etymology: from Greek plethōra 'fullness', from plēthein 'be full'

tenacious.definition: tending to keep a firm hold of something; clinging or adhering closely
tenacious.example: The ivy was tenacious and refused to let go of the wall.

harangue.definition: a lengthy and aggressive speech aimed at persuading someone to do something
harangue.example: The coach harangued the team during halftime to motivate them to win the game.
harangue.etymology: from French harangue (16th century), from Old Italian aringa, from Germanic origin

eschew.definition: to deliberately avoid or keep away from something
eschew.example: In order to maintain his healthy lifestyle, he eschewed fast food and soft drinks.
eschew.etymology: from Old French eschiver (12th century), from Frankish skiuhan 'to frighten off'

mawkish.definition: excessively sentimental or emotional in an artificial or contrived way
mawkish.example: The movie's mawkish ending left many viewers feeling unsatisfied.
mawkish.etymology: from Middle English mawke, a type of gull, probably influenced by Middle Low German mak, 'maggot'

temerity.example: The defendant had the temerity to talk back to the judge during the trial.

lascivious.definition: showing an excessive interest in sexual matters; lewd or licentious
lascivious.example: The song's lascivious lyrics were considered scandalous at the time.
lascivious.etymology: from Middle English, from Old French lascivieux, from Latin lascivus 'playful, wanton'

abate.etymology: Middle English: from Old French abatre, from a- ‘to’ + batre ‘to beat’

comportment.example: her dignified comportment at the funeral
comportment.etymology: early 17th century: from French comportement, from comporter ‘to bear, behave’

indolent.example: he was too indolent to get out of bed
indolent.etymology: mid 17th century: from Latin indolent-, from in- ‘not’ + dolere ‘suffer or feel pain’

languor.definition: the state or feeling of being tired and listless
languor.example: he was overcome by a sudden languor
languor.etymology: late Middle English: from Old French langor, from Latin languor, from languere ‘languish’

pugnacious.definition: eager or quick to argue, quarrel, or fight
pugnacious.example: the increasingly pugnacious demeanor of politicians
pugnacious.etymology: mid 17th century: from Latin pugnax, pugnac- ‘combative’, from pugnare ‘to fight’

sobriquet.definition: a nickname or term of endearment
sobriquet.example: His sobriquet 'The King of Pop' became synonymous with Michael Jackson.

apoplectic.example: He was apoplectic when he found out that his proposal had been rejected.

dilatory.example: His dilatory tactics were starting to frustrate his colleagues.

proselytize.definition: to convert or attempt to convert someone from one religion, belief, or opinion to another
proselytize.example: He spent hours trying to proselytize his atheist friend to become a believer.

untenable.definition: not able to be maintained or defended against attack or objection
untenable.example: His argument was clearly untenable in light of the new evidence.

foible.definition: a minor flaw or shortcoming in character or behavior
foible.example: His foible was his tendency to interrupt people while they were speaking.

indelible.definition: making marks that cannot be removed; not able to be forgotten or removed
indelible.example: The pen had indelible ink that couldn't be erased.
indelible.etymology: From Latin 'indelibilis', from 'in-' meaning 'not' and 'delere' meaning 'to delete, destroy'

quintessential.definition: representing the most perfect or typical example of a quality or class
quintessential.example: The quintessential beach vacation involves lounging on the sand, swimming in the ocean, and soaking up the sun.

surreptitious.definition: kept secret, especially because it would not be approved of
surreptitious.example: He took a surreptitious look at his phone during the meeting.

verisimilitude.definition: the appearance of being true or real
verisimilitude.example: The author's use of vivid details created a sense of verisimilitude in the story.

sardonic.etymology: mid 17th century: from French sardonique or late Latin sardonius, alteration of Greek sardonios (see sardonyx)

evanescent.etymology: early 18th century: from Latin evanescere, from e- (variant of ex-) ‘out of’ + vanescere ‘disappear’

reprobate.definition: an unprincipled person (often used humorously or affectionately).
reprobate.etymology: mid 16th century: from ecclesiastical Latin reprobatus ‘disapproved’, past participle of reprobare (see reprove)

supercilious.definition: behaving or looking as though one thinks one is superior to others.
supercilious.etymology: late 16th century: from Latin superciliosus ‘haughty’, from supercilium ‘eyebrow’ (from super- ‘above’ + cilium ‘eyelid’).

rambunctious.definition: uncontrollably exuberant; boisterous; marked by uncontrollable exuberance
rambunctious.example: The rambunctious children were bouncing off the walls.
rambunctious.etymology: First recorded in 1830-40, perhaps akin to rum and bumptious.

panacea.definition: a remedy for all ills or difficulties; cure-all
panacea.example: Some people believe that laughter is a panacea for many of life's problems.
panacea.etymology: From Greek panakeia 'universal remedy', from pan- 'all' + akos 'cure'.

flummox.example: The complex instructions flummoxed even the experienced technicians.
flummox.etymology: Origin uncertain; perhaps from the phrase 'flummix and fumble'.

idiosyncrasy.definition: a peculiar personality trait or habit; quirk
idiosyncrasy.example: His idiosyncrasy of always wearing mismatched socks amused his colleagues.
idiosyncrasy.etymology: From Greek idiosynkrasia, from idio- 'own, personal' + synkrasis 'mixture'.

gossamer.definition: a fine, filmy substance consisting of cobwebs spun by small spiders; something delicate, light, or flimsy
gossamer.example: The ballerina's gossamer tutu floated ethereally around her as she danced.
gossamer.etymology: From Middle English gossomer, gossomer, gossummer, from Old English gōsmære, literally 'goose-moth'.

calibrate.definition: to adjust or standardize the measurement of a device
calibrate.example: The mechanic had to calibrate the speedometer.

indolent.example: The indolent cat spent the whole day sleeping.

zenith.example: The sun was at its zenith at noon.

enigma.example: The disappearance of the airplane remains an enigma.

peruse.definition: to read or examine something in a thorough or careful way
peruse.example: She perused the contract carefully before signing it.
peruse.etymology: From Latin 'per-,' meaning 'through,' and 'rudis,' meaning 'rough, unpolished.'

gregarious.example: He was a gregarious man who loved to be around people.
gregarious.etymology: From Latin 'gregarius,' meaning 'belonging to a herd or flock.'

elucidate.example: He tried to elucidate his point of view, but she still didn't understand.
elucidate.etymology: From Latin 'e-' meaning 'out,' and 'lucere,' meaning 'to shine.'

solitude.definition: the state of being alone; a lonely or secluded place
solitude.example: She enjoyed the peace and solitude of the countryside.

garrulous.definition: excessively talkative; using too many words
garrulous.example: The garrulous old man talked for hours about his life.

paradox.definition: a statement or proposition that seems self-contradictory or absurd but in reality expresses a possible truth
paradox.example: The concept of an omnipotent and omniscient God creating a stone that is too heavy for Him to lift is a classic example of a paradox.
paradox.etymology: from the Greek word 'paradoxon' meaning 'contrary to expectations'

ephemeral.definition: lasting for a very short time
ephemeral.example: The beauty of a cherry blossom is ephemeral, as the petals fall within days of blooming.
ephemeral.etymology: from the Greek word 'ephēmeros' meaning 'lasting only one day'

trepidation.definition: a feeling of fear or agitation about something that may happen
trepidation.example: I felt a sense of trepidation as I stepped into the dark and unfamiliar room.
trepidation.etymology: from the Latin word 'trepidare' meaning 'to tremble'

apathetic.definition: showing or feeling no interest, enthusiasm, or concern
apathetic.example: The apathetic student didn't bother to do his homework, despite repeated warnings from his teacher.
apathetic.etymology: from the Greek word 'apathēs' meaning 'without feeling'

gloaming.definition: the time of day immediately following sunset
gloaming.example: We enjoyed a picnic in the gloaming.
gloaming.etymology: From Middle English "gloamingen", from Old English "glōmung".

lissome.example: She moved with a lissome grace.

mnemonic.definition: assisting or intended to assist memory
mnemonic.example: I used a mnemonic to remember the order of the planets.

propinquity.definition: nearness in place or time; kinship
propinquity.example: The propinquity of the two towns made them natural trading partners.

vociferous.definition: marked by or given to vehement insistent outcry
vociferous.example: The protesters were vociferous in their demands for change.
vociferous.etymology: From Latin "vociferari", from "voc-" meaning "voice" and "ferre" meaning "to bear".

precarious.definition: not securely held or in position; dangerously likely to fall or collapse
precarious.example: The ladder felt precarious as I climbed up it.
precarious.etymology: Mid 17th century (in the sense ‘dependent on circumstances or chance’): from Latin precarius ‘obtained by entreaty’ (from prex, prec- ‘prayer’) + -ous.

luminous.definition: full of or shedding light; bright or shining, especially in the dark
luminous.example: The moon was luminous in the night sky.
luminous.etymology: Late Middle English: from Old French lumineux or Latin luminosus, from lumen ‘light’.

quandary.definition: a state of uncertainty over what to do in a difficult situation
quandary.example: I was in a quandary about whether to tell the truth or not.

pensive.definition: engaged in, involving, or reflecting deep or serious thought
pensive.example: She sat in a pensive mood, contemplating her future.
pensive.etymology: Late Middle English: from Old French pensif, -ive, from penser ‘think’, from Latin pensare ‘consider’.

perfidious.example: He had a perfidious nature, always looking for ways to deceive those around him.

quiescent.definition: in a state of inactivity or dormancy
quiescent.example: The volcano had been quiescent for many years, but scientists feared it would erupt again soon.
quiescent.etymology: From Latin quiescere, meaning 'to rest' or 'to become quiet'.

temerity.example: She had the temerity to insult her boss in front of the entire company.

rancorous.example: Their rancorous relationship had been strained for years, but they could never seem to resolve their differences.
rancorous.etymology: From Middle English rancour, meaning 'hate' or 'malice'.

euphemism.definition: a mild or indirect word or expression used in place of one considered to be too harsh or blunt
euphemism.example: He used the euphemism 'passed away' instead of 'died' to soften the blow for the grieving family.
euphemism.etymology: From Greek euphēmismos, meaning 'the use of good words' or 'a good omen'.

abscond.definition: to depart secretly and hide oneself

disingenuous.example: Her disingenuous smile betrayed her true feelings.

incorrigible.definition: not able to be corrected, improved, or reformed

pensive.example: She sat in a pensive mood, reflecting on her life.

quixotic.example: His quixotic plan to save the world was met with ridicule.
quixotic.etymology: from the character Don Quixote, who had unrealistic and chivalrous ideals
